description: TO REMOVE THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY SURROUNDING THE COMMUNICATIONS RECEIVED FROM THE PRESIDENT JUNE 8, 1795, CONCERNING THE TREATY BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITIAN.
TO ADJOURN UNTIL MONDAY NEXT.
TO POSTPONE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE RESOLUTION IN WHICH THE SENATE ADVISES AND CONSENTS TO THE RATIFICATION OF A TREATY OF 11/19/1794 BETWEEN THE U.S. AND GREAT BRITAIN.

TO ADOPT THE LAST PARAGRAPH OF THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITIAN, WHICH RECOMMENDS TO THE PRESIDENT TO PROCEED TO FURTHER FRIENDLY NEGOTIATIONS WITH BRITAIN, ON THE SUBJECT OF TRADE.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO RATIFY THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, BY INSISTING ON "ADEQUATE COMPENSATION FOR THE NEGROES AND OTHER PROPERTY OF AMERICAN INHABITANTS, CARRIED OFF FROM THE UNITED STATES".
TO POSTPONE THE RESOLUTION TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, IF CERTAIN CONDITIONS RESPECTING TRADE ARE MET.

TO ADOPT THE FIRST PARAGRAPH OF THE RESOLUTION TO RATIFY THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITIAN ON CONDITION THAT THERE BE ADDED TO THE SAID TREATY AN ARTICLE WHEREBY IT SHALL BE AGREED TO SUSPEND THE OPERATIONS OF SO MUCH OF THE 12TH ARTICLE AS RESPECTS THE TRAD WITH THE BRITISH WEST INDIES
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THE SENATE RECOMMEND TO THE PRESIDENT TO RENEW THE CLAIMS OF AMERICAN CITIZENS FOR COMPENSATION FOR NEGROES AND OTHER PROPERTY TAKEN FROM THEM BY BRITISH FORCES.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING RATIFICATION OF A TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, BY PROVIDING THAT THE NEGOTIATIONS ON THIS SUBJECT BE CONSIDERED PART OF THE NEGOTIATIONS RECOMMENDED BY THE ACT RESPECTING THE TRADE IN THE BRITISH WEST INDIES.  (P. 187-188)

TO ADOPT THE LAST CLAUSE OF THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING RATIFICATION OF A TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, WHICH CLAUSE PROVIDES THAT THE NEGOTIATION ON THIS SUBJECT SHOULD BE DISTINCT FROM THAT RECOMMENDED BY AN ACT CONCERNING TRADE IN THE BRITISH WEST INDIES.

TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE REJECTING THE LAST CLAUSE OF THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING RATIFICATION OF A TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, WHICH CLAUSE PROVIDES THAT NEGOTIATION ON THIS SUBJECT SHOULD BE DISTINCT FROM THAT RECOMMENDED BY AN ACT CONCERNING TRADE IN THE BITISH WEST INDIES.
TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION RATIFYING THE TREATY OF AMITY, COMMERCE AND NAVIGATION WITH GREAT BRITAIN, AND PROVIDING FOR COMMISSIONS TO SETTLE DISPUTED CLAIMS.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO RESCIND THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY CONCERNING PRESIDENTIAL COMMUNICATIONS RELATIVE TO THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN; BY PROVIDING THAT NO COPY BE MADE OF THE PRESIDENTIAL COMMUNICATIONS CONCERNING THE NOMINATION OF JOHN JAY AS EVOY TO BRITAIN.
TO AGREE TO THE RESOLUTION TO RESCIND THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY CONCERNING CERTAIN PRESIDENTIAL COMMUNICATIONS AND THE NOMINATION OF JOHN JAY AS ENVOY TO BRITIAN.
TO AMEND A COMMITTEE REPORT IN RESPONSE TO AN ADDRESS BY THE PRESIDENT, BY STRIKING OUT THE FOURTH AND FIFTH PARAGRAPHS OF THE REPORT.
TO AMEND A COMMITTEE REPORT IN RESPONSE TO AN ADDRESS BY THE PRESIDENT, BY AMENDING THE FIFTH PARAGRAPH BY STRIKING "EVERY WAY".
TO ADOPT THE COMMITTEE REPORT IN RESPONSE TO AN ADDRESS BY THE PRESIDENT.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF JOHN RUTLEDGE TO BE CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY OF PEACE WITH THE LATE HOSTILE TRIBES OF INDIANS NORTHWEST OF THE OHIO RIVER.

TO AMEND THE SENATE RESPONSE TO A PRESIDENTIAL MESSAGE CONCERNING THE SHOWING OF THE FRENCH COLORS; BY STRIKING OUT "THAT THE PRESIDENT BE REQUESTED TO ASSURE THE FRENCH NATION THROUGH THE PROPER ORGAN".
TO AMEND "AN ACT TO PROMOTE THE PROGRESS OF USEFUL ARTS AND TO REPEAL THE ACT HERETOFORE MADE FOR THAT PURPOSE"; BY SUBJOINING THE PROVISO CONCERNING PATENTS FOR ALIENS.
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING THE TREATY WITH ALGIERS, SO TO READ, "THAT THE SENATE DO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF A TREATY WITH THE DEY OF ALGIERS".
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH THE DEY OF ALGIERS.
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO RATIFY THE TREATY WITH ALGIERS, BY STATING THAT SAID RESOLUTION WAS PASSED UNANIMOUSLY.
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO RATIFY A TREATY WITH SPAIN, IN ORDER TO STATE THAT SAID RESOLUTION WAS PASSED UNANIMOUSLY.

TO AMEND S. 37, (APP. 5/28/1796, 1 STAT 482), A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE RELIEF OF PERSONS IMPRISONED FOR DEBT, BY MAKING IT UNNECESSARY FOR THE DEBTORS OATH TO BE ADMINISTERED BY A JUSTICE OF THE PEACE.
TO CONSENT TO THE APPOINTMENT OF OLIVER ELLSWORTH TO BE CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.
TO POSTPONE A COMMITTEE REPORT REGARDING A CHARGE OF PERJURY BROUGHT AGAINST SENATOR MARSHALL OF KENTUCKY, IN ORDER TO CONSIDER THE RESOLUTION CONCERNING ADMISSABLE EVIDENCE IN THIS CASE.

TO AMEND THE COMMITTEE REPORT REGARDING A CHARGE OF PERJURY AGAINST SENATOR MARSHALL; AMENDMENT TO STRIKE: "AND THEY ARE ALSO OF THE OPINION THAT, AS THE CONSTITUTION DOES NOT GIVE JURISDICTION TO THE SENATE, THE CONSENT OF THE PARTY CANNOT GIVE IT; THERFORE, THE SAID MEMORIAL SHOULD BE DISMISSED".
TO ADOPT THE COMMITTEE REPORT TO DISMISS THE MEMORIAL CONCERNING THE CHARGE OF PERJURY AGAINST SENATOR MARSHALL.
TO POSTPONE THE CONSIDERATION OF THE NOMINATION OF HENRY KNOX AND OTHERS AS COMMISSIONERS ON THE PART OF THE UNITED STATES TO FIX CERTAIN BOUNDARIES BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN.
TO COMMIT H.R. 155, (APP. 5/28/1796, 1 STAT 477), A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE RELIEF AND PROTECTION OF AMERICAN SEAMEN, TO A SELECT COMMITTEE.
TO CONCUR WITH THE HOUSE IN THE AMENDED VERSION OF H.R. 156, (APP. 4/20/17968 1 STAT 454), A BILL TO AUTHORIZE AND DIRECT THE SECRETARY OF WAR TO PLACE CERTAIN PERSONS NAMED ON THE PENSION LIST.

TO AMEND H.R. 162, A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF CERTAIN OFFICERS WHO HAVE DIED OF WOUNDS RECEIVED IN THE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES SINCE MARCH 1789; BY EXTENDING BENEFITS TO WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF COMMISSIONED OFFICERS OF THE CONTINETAL ARMY WHO DIED OF WOUNDS RECEIVED BEFORE MAY, 1778.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF H.R. 162.
TO AMEND H.R. 162, BY EXCLUDING THE MILITIA FROM THE BENEFITS OF THE LAW.
TO PASS H.R. 162.

TO AMEND H.R. 155, (APP. 5/28/1796, 1 STAT 477), A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR RELIEF AND PROTECTION OF AMERICAN SEAMEN; BY SLIGHTLY ALTERING THE SECTION OUTLINING PROCEDURE WHEN A SHIP IS DETAINED OR IMPRESSED BY A FOREIGN POWER.
TO REFER A COMMITTEE REPORT REGARDING H.R. 144, (APP. 5/6/1796, 1 STAT 461), A BILL TO AUTHORIZE A LOAN FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES, TO A SPECIAL COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS.
TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION OF A COMMITTEE REPORT CONCERNING H.R. 144 AND AMENDMENTS.
TO DELAY CONSIDERATION OF THE COMMITTEE REPORT ON H.R. 144.
TO AMEND H.R. 144, BY ELIMINATING THE CLAUSE WHICH PROVIDES THAT THE UNITED STATES SHALL PAY THE SURPLUS OF DEBT, NOT MET BY THE SALE OF CERTAIN LOTS IN WASHINGTON.
TO AMEND H.R. 144, BY INCLUDING IN THE FIRST SECTION OF THE BILL, CONSIDERATION OF "ALL CHARGES AND EXPENSES" INCURRED, IN MAKING SAID LOAN.
TO PASS H.R. 144.

TO AMEND H.R. 135, (APP. 5/18/1796, 1 STAT 464), A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE SALE OF UNITED STATES LANDS IN THE TERRITORY NORTHWEST OF THE OHIO RIVER, AND ABOVE THE MOUTH OF THE KENTUCKY RIVER; BY EXTENDING THE RIGHTS OF THE BILL TO ANYONE. (PRESIDENT OF TE SENATE VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE).
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF AN EXPLANATORY ARTICLE OF THE TREATY WITH GREAT BRITAIN, TO BE ADDED TO THE EXISTING TREATY.

TO AMEND H.R. 137, (APP. 5/19/1796, 1 STAT 469), A BILL TO REGULATE TRADE AND INTERCOURSE WITH THE INDIAN TRIBES, AND TO PRESERVE PEACE ON THE FRONTIERS, BY PROVIDING THAT NO PENALTY SHALL BE BROUGHT AGAINST AN INDIVIDUAL WHO ILLEGALLY ENTERS INDIAN COUNRY IN SEARCH OF STRAY HORSES OR OTHER STOCK.
TO AMEND H.R. 137, BY ELIMINATING THE PENALTY OF $50 FOR ILLEGALLY ENTERING INDIAN COUNTRY.
TO PASS H.R. 137.

TO AMEND A COMMITTEE REPORT RESPECTING A NEW STATE TO BE FORMED OUT OF TERRITORY SOUTH OF THE OHIO RIVER; BY SUBSTITUTING A REPORT AND RESOLUTION TO ACKNOWLEDGE THAT SAID TERRITORY IS NOW ONE OF THE UNITED STATES BY THE NAME OF TENNESSEE, AND ENTITLED TOREPRESENTATION IN CONGRESS.

TO AMEND H.R. 164, (APP. 5/31/1796, 1 STAT 488), A BILL TO MAKE PROVISION FOR THE PAYMENT OF CERTAIN DEBTS OF THE UNITED STATES, BY AUTHORIZING THE SALE OF SHARES OF STOCK OF THE BANK OF THE UNITED STATES, BELONGING TO THE U.S., AND APPLICATION OF THE PRCEEDS THEREOF TO THE PAYMENT OF SAID DEBTS; INSTEAD OF SELLING CERTIFICATES OF STOCK.
TO AMEND THE TENNESSEE REPORT TO EXPRESS THE SATISFACTION OF THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT WITH THE PROCEEDINGS OF THE TERRITORY OF TENNESSEE IN FORMING A CONSTITUTION.
TO AGREE TO THE AMENDED TENNESSEE REPORT WHICH RECOMMENDS BRINGING IN A BILL CONCERNING THE PROPOSED STATEHOOD OF TENNESSEE.

TO AMEND H.R. 164, BY STRIKING OUT THE CLAUSE GIVING THE COMMISSIONERS AUTHORITY TO SELL ANY SHARES OF THE BANK OF THE UNITED STATES STOCK, AS THEY THINK PROPER, AND TO APPLY THE PROCEEDS TO PAYMENT OF THE SAID DEBTS, INSTEAD OF SELLING CERTIFICATES OF SOCK.
TO AMEND H.R. 164, BY ADDING THE QUOTED WORDS IN THE CLAUSE AUTHORIZING COMMISSIONERS TO SELL AS MANY SHARES OF STOCK IN THE U.S. BANK AS MAY BE PROPER "AND CONSISTENT WITH THE EXISTING LAWS."
TO PASS H.R. 164.
TO AGREE TO THE FORM AND CONTENT OF THE HOUSE BILL FOR THE RELIEF OF MOSES MYERS.

TO AGREE TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO S. 37, (APP. 5/28/1796, 1 STAT 482), A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE RELIEF OF PERSONS IMPRISONED FOR DEBT; SAID AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT PERSONS UNDER PROCESS OF FEDERAL COURTS RECEIVE SAME BENEFITS UNDER LAW AS IN THEIR STAT; IT ALSO PROVIDES THAT DEBTOR REMAIN LIABLE FOR SUING OUT PROCESS AGAINST HIS ESTATE, STATE LAWS NOT WITHSTANDING.
TO RECEIVE THE GENTLEMEN, WHO CLAIM TO BE SENATORS FROM TENNESSEE, AS SPECTATORS UNTIL FINAL SENATE DECISION TO ADMIT TENNESSEE AS A STATE.

TO AMEND S. 46, (APP. 6/1/1796, 1 STAT 491), A BILL TO LAY OUT INTO ONE STATE, THE TERRITORY CEDED BY THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA, AND TO PROVIDE FOR AN ENUMERATION OF THE INHABITANTS BY STRIKING OUT PART OF THE 1ST SECTION IN ORDER TO MOVE TO INSERT A NW PART WHICH PROPOSED THAT A NEW STATE UNDER THE NAME AND TITLE OF "TENNESSEE" BE RECEIVED INTO THE UNION, AND ENTITLED TO ONE REPRESENTATIVE.
TO AMEND A MOTION RELATING TO S. 46, BY ELIMINATING THE REQUIREMENT FOR "THEIR FORMING A CONSTITUTION CONSISTENT WITH THE ORDINANCE OF CONGRESS, JULY 13, 1787".
TO AMEND S. 46, BY ADDING A SECTION OUTLINING THE PROCEDURE AND REQUIREMENTS FOR TENNESSEE STATEHOOD.
TO PASS S. 46.
TO POSTPONE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE RESOLUTION ASKING FOR A CONFERENCE ON S. 46.
TO DISPENSE WITH THE RULES AND ORDER THIRD READING OF THE HOUSE BILL TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT TO LAY, REGULATE AND REVOKE EMBARGOES, DURING THE ENSUING RECESS OF CONGRESS.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THE HONORABLE WILLIAM BLOUNT, AND WILLIAM COCKE, WHO HAVE PRODUCED CREDENTIALS OF BEING DULY ELECTED SENATORS FOR THE STATE OF TENNESSEE, BE ADMITTED TO TAKE THE OATH NECESSARY.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF A TREATY, MADE ON BEHALF OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK WITH CERTAIN TRIBES OF INDIANS, KNOWN AS THE SENECA NATION OF CANADA.

TO AGREE TO A MOTION CONCERNING HOUSE RESOLUTIONS RELATIVE TO THE BALANCES FOUND DUE BY COMMISSIONERS FOR SETTLING ACCOUNTS BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE INDIVIDUAL STATES WHICH MOTION PROPOSES THAT A CERTAIN BOOK BE BROUGHT TO THE SENATE FOR INSPECTON.
TO ADOPT A COMMITTEE REPORT WHICH PROVIDES FOR THE PAYMENT BY THE UNITED STATES OF CERTAIN SUMS, AND THE SUPPLYING OF A FRIGATE TO ALGIERS.

TO AMEND THE SENATE BILL, TO INCREASE THE COMPENSATION ALLOWED TO THE MEMBERS OF THE LEGISLATURE, AND CERTAIN OFFICERS OF THE GOVERNMENT, FOR A LIMITED TIME; BY STRIKING OUT REFERENCE TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS.
TO AMEND THE COMPENSATION BILL BY ALLOWING 25 PERCENT INCREASE TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS, AND CERTAIN OTHERS, TO BEGIN JAN. 1, 1797, AND TO CONTINUE FOR TWO YEARS.
TO PASS THE SENATE BILL TO PUNISH FRAUDS COMMITTED ON THE BANK OF THE UNITED STATES. (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE).
TO PASS THE COMPENSATION BILL.

TO RECEDE FROM A SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE ACCOUNTS RESOLUTIONS; AMENDMENT PROPOSED TO CALL UPON THE DEBTOR STATES ONLY FOR THE SUM WHICH THEY HAD ASSUMED, OVER AND ABOVE WHAT PROVED TO BE THEIR REAL DEMAND AGAINST THE UNITED STATES.
TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL TO AMEND AN ACT TO ASCERTAIN AND FIX THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT OF THE UNITED STATES, BY STRIKING OUT ALL REFERENCE TO LIGHT DRAGOONS.
TO PASS S. 52, (APP. 3/2/1797, 1 STAT 497), A BILL TO ACCOMODATE THE PRESIDENT.
TO PASS H.R. 220, (APP. 3/2/1797, 1 STAT 497), AN ACT TO AUGMENT THE COMPENSATION OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL.

TO RECEDE FROM A SEMATE AMENDMENT TO THE ACCOUNTS RESOLUTIONS WHICH PROPOSED TO CALL UPON THE DEBTOR STATES ONLY FOR THE SUM WHICH THEY HAD ASSUMED OVER AND ABOVE WHAT PROVED TO BE THEIR REAL DEMAND AGAINST THE UNITED STATES.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF S. 54, (APP. 3/3/1797, 1 STAT 507) A BILL TO ALTER THE TIME FOR THE NEXT MEETING OF CONGRESS.
TO PASS THE SENATE BILL TO AUTHORIZE THE PRESIDENT TO LAY, REGULATE AND REVOKE EMBARGOES.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH THE CREEK INDIANS, PROVIDED IT IS AMENDED TO INCLUDE A PROVISO CONCERNING ANNEXATION OF A PORTION OF LAND, FIVE MILES SQUARE.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH THE CREEK INDIANS PROVIDING THAT THE STATE OF GEORGIA CONSENT TO THE TRANSFER OF CERTAIN RIGHTS.
TO PASS S. 54, (APP. 3/3/1797, 1 STAT 507), A BILL TO ALTER THE TIME FOR THE NEXT MEETING OF CONGRESS.

TO PASS H.R. 237, (APP. 3/3/1797, 1 STAT 516), A BILL TO AUTHORIZE AN EXPENDITURE AND MAKE AN APPROPRIATION FOR THE PROSECUTION OF THE CLAIMS OF CERTAIN CITIZENS OF THE UNITED STATES FOR PROPERTY CAPTURED BY THE BELLIGERENT POWERS.
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION TO REQUEST THE PRESIDENT TO INITIATE TREATIES WITH INDIAN TRIBES WITH CLAIMS TO CERTAIN WESTERN LANDS CEDED BY THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA TO THE UNITED STATES.

TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION OF A MOTION THAT THREE READINGS IN ONE DAY OF H.R. 236, (APP. 3/3/1797, 1 STAT 508), AN ACT MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE MILITARY AND NAVAL ESTABLISHMENTS FOR THE YEAR 1797, SHALL NOT BE DRAWN INTO PRECEDENT HEREAFTER, AND THE ENATE WILL NOT HEREAFTER ORIGINATE ANY BILL APPROPRIATING MONEY AT ANY TIME AFTER 10 DAYS BEFORE THE DAY ON WHICH THE SECOND SESSION OF ANY CONGRESS WILL EXPIRE.
